title: Meet Australia's most powerful dealmaker in 2019
text:
A few dealmakers were unlucky to miss out. Jabe Jerram and Dyson Bowditch are making a success of JPMorgan’s capital markets-led push. The bank’s local leader, Paul Uren, moved to a regional role but he’s got JPMorgan to the point where it’s firing across equity, debt and M &A deals. The league tables show it.

Morgan Stanley’s Richard Wagner hasn’t pulled his customary rabbit out of the hat this year – yet – but his bankers, including Andrew Hunter and Luke Boeg, have picked off lucrative mandates.

Citi’s Tony Osmond is one of the industry’s most respected bankers, while private equity and industrials banker Dragi Ristevski is turning Citi into a sponsor powerhouse, winning high-profile sell-side mandates. Deutsche Bank’s Anthony Miller and Alex Cartel keep the Germans in the race, despite ructions offshore.

1. Michael Stock

Stock has become the most talked-about man in Australian investment banking. A polarising figure, the Jefferies country head set up Australia’s newest bank and led from the front with a bunch of mandates more established outfits couldn’t get near. He can’t topple the might of UBS or Macquarie Capital in the league tables, but he has a strong presence and gives his former colleagues at UBS and Credit Suisse plenty to think about.

Client service is his calling card; he is meticulous, strategic and keen for the firm to lead leveraged finance. Most notably, he advised KKR on its successful $3 billion leveraged bid for Arnott’s and Nine, as it seeks to buy out Macquarie Radio.

2. Aidan Allen & Anthony Sweetman

Advertisement

The pair co-head investment banking for UBS Australasia and Sweetman is also the bank’s co-country head. They’re jokingly referred to as Australian banking’s odd couple, and their own team jokes that they wouldn’t be out of place on Married At First Sight.

Sweetman is the UBS mainstay who has stepped up as long-time colleagues Matthew Grounds and Guy Fowler moved on; meanwhile, Allen won the bank a major role in Woolworths’ proposed $10 billion liquor spin-off. The pair are lucky to have the likes of capital markets whiz Robbie Vanderzeil, industrials bankers Geoff Davis, Nick Brown and Nick Alexander, real estate banker Tim Church and Melbourne head Kelvin Barry on side.

Advertisement

3. Christian Johnston

Some big-name retirements this year have left the Goldman Sachs head of investment banking arguably Australia’s most experienced M &A banker. His strength is keeping on top of his blue-chip client list – think BHP, Oil Search and Treasury Wine Estates – but his challenge is bringing through Goldman’s next generation of stars. Insiders reckon Zac Fletcher and Tim Freeman are winning a lot of work and financing banker Chris Champion hustles hard, while Johnston keeps Nick Sims close. The firm’s big money spinner is its special situations team, run by Simon Rothery and David Gribble.

4. Joe Fayyad

After two years rebuilding BAML’s Australian investment bank, Fayyad proved it could now play in the big leagues when he helped stitch up Brookfield’s complex $4.4 billion bid for Healthscope.

That deal, in which BAML was sole adviser to Brookfield, single-handedly put BAML and its big balance sheet back in the conversation. Fayyad and his newly put together senior team – including Jonathan Denby, Dan Janes, Mark Warburton and Chris Gronow – have since won work for the likes of Macquarie Group, DEXUS and Aveo.

5. Tim Joyce & John Pickhaver

Macquarie Capital’s strength is the size of its team. Joyce and Pickhaver’s positions as co-heads put them on the list, but the spot could be shared with several of the pair’s senior dealmakers, who increasingly find themselves reporting offshore. The Macquarie team is stable and it is important it dominates the bank’s home market, particularly with new CEO Shemara Wikramanayake watching over the group. TMET banker Darren Keogh, Jeremy Tasker (sponsors), Russell Keating (resources), David Mustow (consumer), Geoff Joyce (M &A) and Marianne Birch (FIG) are top of the class.

The AFR Magazine annual Power issue is out Friday, October 4, inside The Australian Financial Review. Follow AFR Mag on Twitter and Instagram.
description: Jefferies Australia's new CEO Michael Stock has become the most talked-about man in Australian investment banking and tops the AFR Magazine's hotly anticipated list of dealmakers.
